number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												"Stuck in a Ditch Simulator 2014" is the finest off-road driving game to date. The terrain melts like realistic butter under your 5 ft diamter tires as you struggle against that ♥♥♥♥♥, nature. You ford rivers and climb over mountains in your soviet era monster truck as you try to piece together the story. The Russian outback is a post apocalyptic mud factory covered in "cloaking" which you must overcome by actually getting places, which is much harder than it sounds. After setting up your own objects, cause ♥♥♥♥ you the game is not going to give you any, you trek into the woods in search of the Lumber Camp. After finally getting the the camp you will realize you are not equiped to do anything there at all. Thats right yopu naive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, You will need like 3 or 4 trucks there equiped with trailers, cranes, extra fuel tanks, and repair attachments, and that is just scratching the surface. Getting that stuff there is going to be really hard. You'll have to unlock trucks and attachemnts as you go and expolore more of the map. If there was some sort of Truck Dark Souls; This is it! Perhaps Lofty praise, but the game seems to just lay out some mechanics and let you go off into the world and try and exploit them as you tackle and unforgiving environment. Visually the game is absolutely stunning, not all the textures are really that sharp or impressive but all the ones that count are. The Deformation of the terrain is strangely hypnotic. Every instant looks like a Bob Ross painting except there is a badass truck ripping through the center of it!  If you think trucks are rad, or have any interest in off-roading, then this is the game for you. Good luck Comrade!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Took the plunge and was not disappointed! This is pretty much the best true off-road simulator you'll find but bear in mind its NOT A RACING GAME. Speed is not the name of the game here but rather realistic navigation of a deep Russian forest! You've got mud, pools/streams/rivers/oceans of water, steep inclines, dried out riverbeds, dense forests, sharp switchbacks up a mountain side... a good variety of terrain.The game is incredibly simple in its objectives but its just plain fun to set out on a new map and find the best routes to load up and then deliver loads of lumber. Yes, thats the current way to "beat" the maps - you need to load lumber either with a crane or by going to specific lumber yards and loading up on short, medium or long logs and then hauling them across the map to drop points. AND THE PHYSICS! Damn, best mud and water physics I've seen for a driving game. Your tires will dig massive ruts, water has realistic currents and will flow even between your tires... its amazing. Where there was once a pristine trail could become a muddy hell at the end of the map after you've hauled heavy loads through it. As for the vehicles you've got an assortment of Russian trucks such as an old dually, a recon jeep and then you can even get up to massive 8x8 rolling fortresses that can only be stopped by the worst mud pits imaginable. Speaking of that recon jeep, each map starts out cloaked in black swirls/clouds that prevent you from seeing all the map right away. The cloaks can be removed simply by moving near them but they are often hidden away in deep forest/rough terrain and its pretty fun to scout out the unkown with your trusty jeep and reveal the map!The devs totally plan on supporting the game into the future and will be surely adding new trucks, maps and even new objectives/features so this already simple but fun game will become even greater with time!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												If you're interested solely in the idea of driving offroad through fairly realistic mud/water/rocks then this game does that very well.  It's not realistic to the point of being punishing but it does a good job of staying very far away from being arcade and it's satisfying to watch the simulated mud moving around as you drive through it.As for the rest of the game...it's more of a tech demo...you can load logs onto a truck from 1 or 2 log locations on the map and deliver them elsewhere to complete an achievement...you can take a trailer load of 'garage' parts to 1 or 2 spare garage locations on a map to unlock them(this is where you repair and get fuel trailers/change tires/change equipment on the trucks such as the crane attachment)....and you can offroad to "cloaking" places that obscure your map view in the beginning.  Outside of those few tasks the rest of the content has to come from you....maybe you got stuck and switch to another truck to come winch yourself out....maybe you broke a truck or need fuel so you grab yet another truck to bring repair points/fuel to yourself.....or maybe you drove through the same spot a few times and now the ruts have made you stuck.  Things can be a bit more fun if you have a friend or two(not random people) to play multiplayer with so you can convoy around together.  Over all the maps seem to be a bit small at roughly 3kmx3km(can take a while crawling in mud) and the lack of any additional missions or non-player AI means the game really does feel like a tech demo and given the terrible relations the devs have with the community I bet it'll stay like a tech demo.........BUT that doesn't stop me from recommending it to anybody that wants to do some offroading from the comfort of their home.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I absolutely love this game but it's not for everyone. Its essentially a simulator, but the physics are actually great unlike most simulators. The goal is essentially to pick up and deliver loads of lumber. But theres map to reveal, garages to unlock by delivering supplies, and repair and gas trailers to service your trucks (which you will need to do). Theres lots of (functional) customization to do and each truck has its own options. Including having a fully controllable crane!The game mechanics include deforming mud. So as roads are driven on the roads will degrade visibly as you leave your ruts in your wake. Trucks have lockable differentials and all wheel drive for when you need to get through the really tough terrain, which is most of the time. Trucks that are carrying loads feel considerably heavier than empty trucks. The physics are just awesome. My gf laughs at me but I swear, I've been driving down a rough road at about 3mph, and I've been literally on the edge of my seat because I'm afraid I'm going to tip the truck and lose my load after a long trek.If you enjoy Ice Road Truckers or watching Bonecrusher drive the muddy Maine logging roads in American Loggers, or you just love trucks like me then you're going to enjoy this game.My one complaint, and I am not alone in this, is the camera. It is pretty unweildy but I got mostly used to it. But there are times that you just can't get the view you need. The developers claim they are going to fix this in an update but that hasn't happened yet at the time I'm writing this.Other than that, the game delivers exactly what they say and they do it well. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												So,I just want to state that the first thing I did was to play multiplayer, and it was within the first 10 minutes of playing the game, that I learnt just how far a soft suspension truck is supposed to tilt.I roll to the bottom of a hill, on my roof, helpless with a stalled engine, and no idea how to get out of the situation I had just created.  Laughing at the same time at how I could go and♥♥♥♥♥♥up so fast.Anyway, I do what anyone would do, I hit every key looking for the chat button, "Ah, it's Y", I think to myself.  I then proceeded to plead to my comrades to save me!In the effort to save me, my friend Crevarski gets pulled over the edge of the hill and ends up stuck at the bottom of it, ensnared by all the surrounding stones deeper in the pit.This was, as you might assume, was unbelievably hilarious.We then both proceed to beg for the random player to save us.In his attempts to save us, he is then also pulled off the cliff, just to roll onto his roof on top of me.This led to tears of laughter on my end.Within the first 10 minutes, I knew my money was well invested, just because I've never laughed so much at having a lack of understanding the game.  The game is just hilarious as you go from blunder to blunder, stalling engines in every possible way possible for the first few hours.Once you're past that part of the game, and you start getting good at traversing the environment in your behemoths, it occurs to you that 1 truck is not going to cut it when tackling this unforgiving terrain!  Leading you to try and get a team sorted, where you'll have to assign everyone a task.  Such as 2 log haulers, and the other 2 as the support, dealing in the winching, repairing and refueling!(For those of you that don't enjoy multiplayer, you can switch to any truck unlocked at any time to go and save the one you just drowned in 'quick-mud')Anyway, this game is so unbelievably addictive, not just for the strangely addictive gameplay, but for the amount of teamwork that is required for a driving simulator, that even the 'crème de la crème' of driving games manage to skim the surface of.Plus, with the game being relatively new, I will ignore its minor flaws, such as the camera being annoying at times, and a few missing options that would of been nice, but aren't exactly going to ruin your time, as I'm sure most of these annoyances will be addressed very soon!I would DEFINITELY recommend this game to anyone that is interested in off-roading 'AND' games like Euro Truck Simulator.8.5/10

												This review is based on the game as it came at the time I bought it (a few days ago) including all updates and patches that it would've had at that time.If you like the concept of this game and enjoy simulators then I doubt this game will disappoint. The graphics are gorgeous. The way the vehicles cut through the mud, brush past trees and slosh through water is all done superbly. I have never known another game that comes even close to simulating ground deformation in this way. The more you drive the tracks in big trucks, the more tricky sections can become churned up, giving you increasing challenges to get through. The level of detail on the vehicles is brilliant - swinging ropes, moving running gear, smoke and heat effects - it's all there. Although one thing that isn't there is any drivers. It seems a shame that in such an immersive simulator as this, the trucks appear to be just driving around magically by themselves. In terms of game-play, having a certain number of 'drivers' to use per map might have been a nice touch, but it's still a fantastic game even with innumerable invisible drivers.There's no music and it doesn't need any. The sounds of the vehicles are spot on. The roar of the really big diesel engines is throaty and satisfying, the transmission whines on the little Uaz truck and the thudding and clunking as you crawl over rough terrain is just right. The ambient sounds are also great. It's a bit like a sounds of nature relaxation CD (until you fire-up a truck of course).The maps are all very similar in visual appearance and there are no weather effects, just day & night, but each contains unique challenges.Within minutes of playing the game I hated the two camera views. The fixed 3rd person view seems useless, most of the time all you can see in this view is the back of the truck. The mouse-controlled view is the one to use, but it seems to be anchored to the truck in a strange place so it rotates awkwardly, it doesn't zoom out far enough, and when you do zoom out it automatically zooms back in again after a few seconds. Within hours of playing the game, I'd got used to the awkward camera angle and reconciled that when you're off-roading, you don't get to see all around the vehicle, or which way the steering wheels are turning etc. After continued playing the camera angle bothers me far less, but it would still be nice to zoom out more.If you like driving big trucks off road and have perhaps longed for a game that effectively simulates mud when off-road driving (which I have), then this is possibly the greatest game ever made. There is plenty to do so long as you enjoy the concept - scouting the terrain to uncloak the map, locating, repairing and refuelling additional trucks, keeping all your trucks fuelled and repaired, towing and winch recovery, setting up new garages and collecting and delivering loads of timber. The two main styles of play I have found so far have been scouting in the small truck, which gives a 'trials' type off-roading experience, picking the best route across terrain with no tracks, finding gaps to wind through trees, pushing through scrub and wading through uncharted depths. Then there's the more 'convoy' style of driving. Perhaps taking a couple of log trucks and a fuel tanker along wide (or at least, the widest you can manage to find) forestry tracks, using the vehicles together to find the best routes and recover, winch and tow each other when needed (and trying not to get all 3 of them stuck).However, if you just go out and drive in a truck to try and get from A to B, then auto-restore your vehicle back to the starting point if you crash and try over, you'll probably get bored quickly. I think you need to actually enjoy trying to recover stuck vehicles to appreciate this game, it's as much about vehicle recovery and problem solving as it is about driving.Moving long trailer loads is a nightmare, and that's exactly how it should be. It's incredibly challenging and rewarding to take big curtain sided trailers or long loads of logs from A to B without spilling the load, inching forward and back at corners to get the right angle, winching up muddy inclines and nervously crawling through water crossings.I don't even want to mention mods because this game is amazing without them, but I've gone and mentioned them now. Mods would be nice. It'd be nice to be able to add vehicles without them replacing existing vehicles in the game, and to get some new maps with a different look to them. But really, if you want to drive big trucks in mud, then this game allows you to just that, and it does so brilliantly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Spintires is an absolutely unique game. In a world where people want to race in amazing cars or have RPG-esque progression unlocks for their driving simulators, it instead presents an alternative style of gameplay. What you do is deliver garage and log points to objectives, but that is more of a framework for the game which can be completely ignored. The game is about mudding, obviously. If you haven't been mudding, you may not "get it." Unfortunately, it's one hell of an expensive hobby, so this is a great alternative. If you haven't had the experience of it, you may fail to realize that parts of the game that seem annoying or tedious are actually good times. Getting stuck in the mud is fun. Unsticking yourself is even more fun. Unsticking another person's truck because you're a better driver is the best. Breaking your truck slamming into a tree because you wanted to slalom down a hill at top speed is also fun, as is rolling off a hill with switchbacks on it. Delivering logs and garage points is alright too, I guess.The real crux of it is this: the game had a rough spell in development and the team they have on this is too small. It's a wonderful game with mods aplenty for the people who this style of game will appeal to. They need to prove themselves by finishing this game out (small amount of development effort still needed) before they can start on Spintires 2 or another team with a bigger budget will jump on it and create a spiritual successor. If it meets your price point and you're reading these reviews, you're invested enough you might consider getting it. For everyone else, let's see where this new subgenre will go before you throw money at it. It may ruin you for anything that ought to have mud that doesn't though, it makes those games feel like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 90s arcade style racers or so barebones you can't enjoy them anymore. The GTA and Farm Simulator series feel like they run a physics engine from two decades ago after playing this and it's physics are pretty bad.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												Over 1 year later, 9/10. > Workshop support added> Game is a bit smoother> Different maps than beforeOnly downside is the developer-publisher relationship that has resulted in many effed up situations. Hopefully this is resolved in the future.--Fun game. TONS to say about the good. I'd rate it a 8/10 for the Legacy build. 6/10 for the current update.ALL data gets written over with updates. Backup before you update... or change from legacy to current build...> Mod support is amazing, beware of the custom maps since not all work properly.> Lots of fun aspects to mess with in the .XML files but unfortunatly you can't earn achievements unless you switch back and forth with backups of the media.zip folder (I do this). > Easy to get achievments if you look at guides and are willing to attempt.> Controller support is amazing. Fun to play with both a controller, and a wheel. Button mapping is simple and easy to access.

												Great game.  Can be very challenging and frustrating especially on Hardcore mode.  The physics in the game are well above par and the destructable terrain looks amazing.  If you have any spare cash laying around and enjoying playing in the mud then think about picking this game up especially if it happens to be on sale.  There are a few drawbacks that the devs have said they are working on:camera - hard to control and get where you want to lookmore maps - if you are unable to play online this game can get dry quick unless you can get some modsthings that I think need to be worked:chat - when you first open the chat bar online sometimes it will close for no reasonin game voice chat needs to be addedmore than one winch use at a timethese are just little things that I would like to see done and they don't out way the reason not to get the game.  I love and record videos of the game that you can watch on my profile.Get the game.  Offroad is fun when the terrain is destructible.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is an oddity it has no right to be this good . The idea of a game where the environment is trying to do you in should not work . Yet I love it . There are a billion and one tear round like a fool driving games but this is something new . You have to drive slowly and face it the trucks dont move that fast even when you do try lol . Add the winch mechanics to get you out of a jam which you will frequently and you have a really enjoyable game that gives you a real sense of achievemnt when you end up with a truck wedged in and either winch your way out or bring in another truck to help . Brains are needed to get anywhere with this . It isnt perfect the cloaked areas you have to drive to the exact centre of can be a nightmare to get to and there is next to no documentation on how to do things . No in truck view and an external camera thats twitchy as hell but yet its still a great game . The devs are still polishing and adding to it so it will only get better . In Soviet Russia even the mud hates you !

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Outstanding, fun to play sim.  A well implemented simulation of something that I never would have thought would make a great game: Logging with Cold War era Russian off-road vehicles. It can be a bit of a grind sometimes, but that somehow just adds to the fun and the realsim.  My only complaint is with single player mode.  You can only 'drive' one vehicle at a time, and sometimes need to switch to a vehicle halfway across the map to deliver fuel or perform repairs.  This actually takes away from the realism as in real-life these vehicles would be going out their business as you complete your runs.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Great Offroad simulator, I have played every offroad game that has come out in the last ten years, and spin tires is one of the best. As far as a mud driving simulator it is in a class of its own, the overall feel of the vehicles in the mud is really spot on, the way that the suspension reacts and the trucks wieght shifts around is very impressive. I wish the game handled high speeds better, I understand that the whole point of the game is to carefully navitgate the dangerous terain but every truck becomes very unstable at higher speeds (which is still pretty slow). If the engine could handle speed better it would really open up a lot of options for the modding community. That said i would still highly recomend this game to any offroad enthusiest, for me it is a very relaxing game, just strolling my 100 ton 8 wheel drive truck through the country side, listening to the birds and the churning mud under my tires, It's almost zen-like.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												If you enjoy sliding around a track in the latest piece of Italian exotica, this is not the game for you. If, however, you like the sound of crawling along at single digit speeds in an old Soviet truck that gets stuck easily, then look no further.In summary, Spintires won't be for everyone. If you're like myself and enjoy a good sim then I highly recommend you give this game a chance. The one (and currently only) objective on each map is to deliver 8 pieces of lumber from one end of the map to the other. Where the fun begins is how the maps react to your vehicles. The mud is the star of the show, without a doubt. If you repeatedly use a particular track, it will get more and more churned up and become increasingly difficult to use. There are further obstacles to contend with such as fast flowing rivers, steep adverse cambers and narrow forested tracks.The vehicles are lovingly modelled and all of them offer some benefit over the others. You don't start a level with all the available vehicles for that map unlocked. They are often hidden in the wilderness. And then when you do find them, they will regularly need repairing or fuelling, or sometimes even both.The multiplayer makes completing the objectives a lot easier as you can move in convoy and help each other out but some maps are still very difficult.While this game still has a long way to go to being called complete, I love it already. Completing a level is very satisfying and the physics are modelled beautifully. I'd highly recommend you give it a shot.

And the joy of taking something where it really shouldn't be. If you like ETS2 and you like offroad, then you will love this. The self satisfaction you get from removing yourself from a sticky situation is grand, and if your a hoarder of achievemnets then this game has many. It's a special game that looks beautiful and does just what you'd expect it to do.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Spintires is an off-road simulator. It's a very niche genre without a whole lot of competition. In fact, the only game you can compare Spintires to on Steam is probably "Off-Road Drive", which is also a great game. As an avid off-roader IRL (as they say), I can attest to this game's ability to scratch that off-roading itch a little bit. Only the real thing is better. The mud and water deformation is amazing (an apparently, award winning). The physics of driving a vehicle off-road is as close to the real thing as I've ever seen in a video game; there is no going fast in this game. The fastest you can go is maybe 20 MPH if you find some paved road (which is rare) and shift it into high gear. Ostensibly, the game is about logging. More accurately, hauling lumber through the Russian backwoods.  That's it, haul lumber from point A to point B, alone or with a "crew" of up to 4. Of course, you could just ignore all that and just go hit the trails, which is also really fun. That said, this game isn't for everyone. My wife watched as, for 15 minutes, a buddy and I struggled, trial-and-errored and fought a piece of terrain which was only about 10 feet long. Let me be clear: 15 minutes to go 10 feet. She couldn't understand the appeal of that, and I can totally understand why many would be turned off by it. But you know, THAT IS OFF-ROADING. That's how it goes down in a real life, sometimes even longer to go an even shorter distance! But off-roaders live for that sort of thing. I absolutely love the technical ability and intestinal fotitude needed to tackle terrain like that. By the way, the winching system is stellar! Since the game is so good at capturing that, this is not an easy game. On top of the technical challenge of maneuvering an 8x8 monstrosity towing a trailer full of long logs through tight slush, your truck has both limited fuel and hit points. Yeah, here comes the pain.There are cons however, ones that luckily can be remedied fairly easily. - The damage model is inconsistent and frankly a bit harsh. I'll be driving my little UAZ 4x4 in some gummy muck, hit a rock a bit larger than my vehicle likes, take it right in the undercarriage and I'll do about 1-7 hit points of damage. Then I'll hit a tree barely any larger than a sapling with my front bumper going slower than when I hit the aforementioned rock and cause 25-55 points of damage! Quite a bit when you have 200 HP. This damage model also COMPLETELY negates using 4WD high; when you find a bumpy but solid road, not a whole lot of mud, you'll be tempted to put it in high to get a little more speed. WELL DON'T. Those tiny little bumps will start hitting you for 10, 15, 25, 50 or more hit points even if you're hitting them with your tires. Found a paved road? Think it's time to shift it into high gear? WRONG. I tried this with on of the big hauler trucks, gathered a decent amount of speed, hit a dip and BAM! 200+ damage in one hit! Why am I being punished for driving 25 MPH on a paved road? I don't get the logic there. I'm not sure what this is supposed to be simulating. Maybe these Russian trucks are made of glass?- The maps. There about 5 or so maps and they are quite large and can take quite a while to explore. However, let's be honest Spintires fans, they're all the same. Yes, some have more water than others, one even has a volcano, but at the end of the day you're spending about 80% of the time driving (and getting stuck in) mud, 10% in water, 5% in dirt and 5% on rocks and other rough terrain. The majority of these maps are covered in impassible forest, with trees so close to each other there's no way to squeeze between them. Also, all too often the terrain texture is grass or dirt, then when you drive on it, it ends up being mud. Deep, gummy, unforgiving mud.  - I don't understand why there isn't an official sandbox mode. It seems to fit this game perfectly. The logging and hauling is great. Tons of fun. A great challenge. But sometimes I just want it to drop me on a map, infinite fuel, damage turned off, let me choose ANY truck in the game and just let me GO, with friends too!- Excuse my language, and I'm sorry if this offends anyone, but the only trucks in the game are Russian sh*tboxes. Gutless wonders, every last of 'em. I don't know if licensing Jeeps, Toyotas and Land Rovers was too expensive or what, but we need something different. Even the big diesel trucks feel way too large and heavy for the amount of power they have, which is probably what it's actually like in the real world. The UAZ is a tiny Jeep imitation, it doesn't need much power, but they give it to you with placid, pizza cutter tires. Imagine taking THAT in the mud. Yeah, you get real cozy with your winch. Broncos, Blazers, Hiluxes, CJs, Wranglers, Patrols, FJ40s... gimmie gimmie gimmie!Finally, this game was born to be modded and has a large and healthy modding community. It's just a matter of time before all of the above gripes are addressed (Workshop integration would be amazing!) So for now, this game is great, but given time, Spintires will become the greatest off-road sim of all time.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												Spintires is an absolutely unique game. In a world where people want to race in amazing cars or have RPG-esque progression unlocks for their driving simulators, it instead presents an alternative style of gameplay. What you do is deliver garage and log points to objectives, but that is more of a framework for the game which can be completely ignored. The game is about mudding, obviously. If you haven't been mudding, you may not "get it." Unfortunately, it's one hell of an expensive hobby, so this is a great alternative. If you haven't had the experience of it, you may fail to realize that parts of the game that seem annoying or tedious are actually good times. Getting stuck in the mud is fun. Unsticking yourself is even more fun. Unsticking another person's truck because you're a better driver is the best. Breaking your truck slamming into a tree because you wanted to slalom down a hill at top speed is also fun, as is rolling off a hill with switchbacks on it. Delivering logs and garage points is alright too, I guess.The real crux of it is this: the game had a rough spell in development and the team they have on this is too small. It's a wonderful game with mods aplenty for the people who this style of game will appeal to. They need to prove themselves by finishing this game out (small amount of development effort still needed) before they can start on Spintires 2 or another team with a bigger budget will jump on it and create a spiritual successor. If it meets your price point and you're reading these reviews, you're invested enough you might consider getting it. For everyone else, let's see where this new subgenre will go before you throw money at it. It may ruin you for anything that ought to have mud that doesn't though, it makes those games feel like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 90s arcade style racers or so barebones you can't enjoy them anymore. The GTA and Farm Simulator series feel like they run a physics engine from two decades ago after playing this and it's physics are pretty bad.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Seeing as this game is wonderful, the developers of this game are taking their time to ensure the updates are high quality. They are currently working on another map for SpinTires (Go check their Forums to find out more)-PROS-1. Game Mechanics - Winches work wonderfully, Mud deformation (could use a tad bit more work)2. Graphics - In my honest opinion, the graphics look astonishing.3. Trucks - Different types. Standard (6x6, and 8x8s)-CONS-1. Multiplayer - As soon as someone joins a game, they either get disconnected, lose connection to Steam, or just leave for no reason. (This is why Multiplayer Saves should be a thing.) *Oovee and IMGN are currently working on this. There looks to be no syncing for mud deformation, no truck sounds for other players (to make it easier, The host can't hear other players engines, but the other player - Bob, for now - can't hear anyone else's engine noises, only his)2. Camera - The camera, for me, is great for taking pictures, but can be a bit of a nuisance for actually playing the game. There should be this camera, and another, like a standard driving game camera where the camera is aimed at the back, and it will rotate around the truck. (Like the Forza Motorsport games)3. As of yet, it's not being update alot (But hey, it's still relatively new... Kinda...) - They are planning to make bigger and better updates to improve the game, but this will take time.For people who just buy the game on a whim and say "I hope it's as good as it looks." Please, download the demo first and try it out for yourself.Overall, I HIGHLY recommend this game if you like off-roading in big trucks, and actually accomplishing something while doing so.*One other thing, is that there are mods for this game, but they will replace certain trucks, and disable achievements. If you ever install a mod, make sure to back up your game files before doing so. :)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is an oddity it has no right to be this good . The idea of a game where the environment is trying to do you in should not work . Yet I love it . There are a billion and one tear round like a fool driving games but this is something new . You have to drive slowly and face it the trucks dont move that fast even when you do try lol . Add the winch mechanics to get you out of a jam which you will frequently and you have a really enjoyable game that gives you a real sense of achievemnt when you end up with a truck wedged in and either winch your way out or bring in another truck to help . Brains are needed to get anywhere with this . It isnt perfect the cloaked areas you have to drive to the exact centre of can be a nightmare to get to and there is next to no documentation on how to do things . No in truck view and an external camera thats twitchy as hell but yet its still a great game . The devs are still polishing and adding to it so it will only get better . In Soviet Russia even the mud hates you !

												Great game, one of the best for physics and graphics, plus it runs really well, even on a low end computer! But, I do have some complaints, most important being the price. $30 is rather too much, I think it should be more like $20, like ETS2. Secondly, the way the camera automatically zooms in after driving for about ten seconds, then there's the fact that the steering wheel doesn't turn, and the way the driver is flailing his arms about does not relate to how you are steering. 												I recommend this game, it has great potential and uses collision detection to manipulate mud physics in a mezmerizing way.I will say, however, is is slow and getting stuck can be very fustrating as it can result in total restarts, basically roguelike mudcrawler. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												I was a supporter early on in the Kickstarter, the technology really interested me and I was excited to play around with it. Upon release I was pleasantly surprised to see that there was stuff to do! Fired it up, played around a bit, then immediately hopped into a coop with a couple friends. Before we knew it, 4 hours had passed. Lots of fun, some problem solving when you get stuck (or, even better, coop problem solving when your friend comes by to pull you out).Be aware it isn't an action game, and won't get by solely on the cool tech. If you enjoy logistical simulators, you'll like this one. If that sounds awful to you, maybe check out some YouTube videos before hand. Actually, do that either way. Smart consumerism and all that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												"Off-Road parking critisism simulator 2015"First of all: who dosent find it fun driving giant trucks through mud that no normal car could get through?This game is the best truck or even driving game i've ever played. I love the graphics, I love the physics, I love the day and night cycles and heck, i even love the mud!Trying to get wood on a long or medium trailer can be a pain in the trailer(truck joke).And you better not loose your logs(another truck joke)  when your truck drowns and dies in a river or puddle which you thought was a puddle but was in fact an endless void of doom and watery-ness.I hope you dont mind getting dirty (no not in that sense) becouse you're going to get so dirty you'll think your truck was brown all along!Suggestions:-They should add more objectives to complete-They should stop being so freakishly picky about loading logs(edit: They kinda fixed this)-they should stop kicking your tires (wow i should stop with the truck jokes) and improve speed on some trucks(edit:I'm dumb, didn't know how to make em go faster >.<)-also there needs to be seasons and weather-low tide and high tideBut all in all its a great game; i'd recommend it to anyone who likes driving and trucks(and mud of course).And yes, it is worth the £19.99

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Absolutely love this game.  Very realistic!  The trucks behave differently depending on if they are loaded (high center of gravity) or unloaded (low cog) or pulling another vehicle.  The swaying of the trucks over rough terrain, the way mud will bog down the truck to the point that you'll get completely stuck, and when you're sitting in one spot, if it's soft ground, your truck will actually sink into the mud sometimes!  I love using the crane for different things, such as assisting rolling over trucks, or grabbing trees to help pull myself along.  Kinda slow paced, but a very awesome simulator!

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Fantastic and very unique game. At first I was a bit sceptical since all you have to do is drive from point a to b through some mud, water, forest... but it didn't take long and I was totally hooked. It is hard to me to explain why this game is so fascinating for me, even though I am not particulary interested in trucks or offroading. And with the mod support and a lot of great user generated maps, there is a lot to do.Since some update I miss the possibility to find logs lying around in hidden places. Now there is a so called log kiosk, where you can spawn the logs that you want to load. That takes a little bit away from the challenge to have to maneuever and position your truck for every log, but other than this, I really love this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												By far the greatest mudding, splashing, hillclimbing, getting stuck simulator ever made. the graphics are gorgeous even on the lowest settings but i tell ya when you crank the graphics up to max and hit that first mud hole the game really shines. even the smallest details of the vehicles are amazing to look at. from the mudd on the tires and the rst of the vehicle, the thick blck smoke of the exhaust or the way the exhaust shakes and rattles when you hit the accelerator. i have never had more fun trying to purposely get stuck with the trucks and try and push my way out. when thijgs get to tough the winch is available to help but even that wont always help in some situations. my only complaint is the damage. sometimes needlessly small bumps do damage and not always a lot but still. it doesnt effect the experince in a whole though. multiplayer is great fun and i love going mudding with my buddies and other random people. getting mods for the game are also fun but at this point all that i have found will disable achievments and multiplayer so hopefully that will get figured out eventually. you can always remove the mods at any time and everything will return to normal. so with all that said the game gets 11/10 of mudd slinging fun

I love the graphics, I love the physics, I love the day and night cycles and heck, i even love the mud!Trying to get wood on a long or medium trailer can be a pain in the trailer(truck joke).And you better not loose your logs(another truck joke)  when your truck drowns and dies in a river or puddle which you thought was a puddle but was in fact an endless void of doom and watery-ness.I hope you dont mind getting dirty (no not in that sense) becouse you're going to get so dirty you'll think your truck was brown all along!Suggestions:-They should add more objectives to complete-They should stop being so freakishly picky about loading logs(edit: They kinda fixed this)-they should stop kicking your tires (wow i should stop with the truck jokes) and improve speed on some trucks(edit:I'm dumb, didn't know how to make em go faster >.<)-also there needs to be seasons and weather-low tide and high tideBut all in all its a great game; i'd recommend it to anyone who likes driving and trucks(and mud of course).And yes, it is worth the £19.99

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I only played a few hours yet but I'll give it a review because I'm amazingly surprised by this game. I thought it was a pointless driving simulator in the woods with muds and rocks everywhere. Well, while it's true there is not much stuff to do right now in the game, I have to say I'm very impressed by the quality of the graphics. They are very realistic and the physics are just so awesome.Pros+ nice graphics with no lag (very stable FPS)+ physics are amazing+ objectives on map (you're not driving endlessly with no goals)+ few different vehicles and customizations+ multi or single+ G27 supportCons- can't join multiplayer games in progress (a bit odd, they should change that)- can't save multiplayer games (or I didnt find how yet?)- camera is awful (but I heard they are working on it)- not that much vehicles and maps (and no workshop for now so we have to hope devs won't leave us alone!)- price could be a little lower cuz the game can become repetivive quickly (i guess it depends alot how much you like sim games)I picked the game on sale for 12$ (including 1 extra copy for a friend). For that price, it's more than a good deal. I have to admit it's so much more fun to play with a friend but you can play single and have lots of fun too. Even if there is not that much goals in the game, you can spend fews hours (when you are a noob) to clear maps. Depends if you rush or not.Overall? It's a good simulator and it handles wheels and gearbox, playable single or multi, that could keep you playing for a few hours if you take time to explore maps (and make achievements at same time). Current price is not abusive while it could be a bit too high if you're not an addicted fan of simulator games. But you can get it on sale from time to time so it's alright.Honestly?  I wish Farming Simulator was close to that in terms of graphics/physics. Combining those 2 games would be crazy (realism of Spintires + features of FS15 = GG).

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												One side of my fully laden truck is bogged down badly after trying to take a shortcut [no such thing in spintires], and the truck starts to lean. Tetering on the brink, neither way I steer the wheels has any positive effect, and both forwards and backwards torque sink the lower wheels deeper and edge the truck further towards tipping point. There are no practical winch points anywhere. At last, some forward forward momentum. I might make it out of this after all, and deliver this last load to the lumber yard. The truck falls over, and the engine stalls, but All is not lost - The logs are still in the cart. I try restarting the engine. It stalls again.I walk back to the garage and get in my truck with a crane attatchment. If I can get the crane truck close enough, a combination of winch and crane might just do the trick. I traverse the boggy and hazardous road between the garage and the tipped log truck as night begins to fall. Upon reaching it, I realise that I'm going to have to get the crane truck into a narrow gap between the log truck and the edge of the nearby forest. And to get there I'm going to have to get through the same bog that I got the first truck stuck in, and move the truck most of the way into the forest. Here goes.10 minutes later, The rescue mission is a failure. The rescue truck was able to get into position into the forest after many turns and wheel revolutions, but now is stuck between two trees with no hope of getting out. The load of logs was spilt after the first attempt to winch the truck back to vertical failed, and now it's out of range of the rescue truck's winch and crane.I walk back to the garage, where my emergency fuel tanker lies waiting, and get the mechanics there to remove the fuel tank and install another crane. While they do this, I have a cup of tea and a vodka or two, while deliberating what to do with the stuck vehicles. Remembering that one of the local towing companies owns an eight wheeler missile truck that they picked up for cheap from a corrupt government official, I decide to just pick up the logs and carry them to the destination, leaving the two trucks stuck in the meantime. The money I get from this job will be able to pay for the towing and repairs for the other two trucks. I go back over to the mechanics and get them to put a log trailer on as well.I arrive at the aparrent scrapyard and assess the situation. It's not as bad as it seems as the logs have fallen and rolled near some fairly stable piece of ground. The loading process goes without a hitch and I set off towards the lumber yard. Everything goes smoothly right until the entrance to the lumber yard. Here, the road is narrow, and I find the exact same thing that happened to the first truck happening again. No problems, I've been through this before, I know how to fix it. Winch onto the nearest tree, and use the extra pulling force to get at least my front wheel out. The truck starts to tip. I detach the winch. I try driving forward. Truck starts tipping further. Into reverse. Ah, some movement, but due to the direction I have to steer in, the trailer starts to jacknife horribly. Still, I push it as far as I can, and realign my front wheels after surveying the ground again. There's a way to the left, but it's between two trees that are in close proximity. The trees do damage to my trailer, but no considerably, and in return they stop my trailer from tipping again. I get through, park in the lumber yard, unload the lumber, then take another swig of vodka. Time to find the number of that towing guy.$30 is cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												A teamwork oriented extreme off-roading logistical puzzle exploration game that believably captures the mesmerizing subtlety of navigating treacherous paths.  It has thankfully evolved from the janky award winning tech demo in 2009 to what is now a polished complete experience.Each vehicle causes you to read the landscape in wildly different ways which cascades down into different configurations of the vehicle.  Screenshots or videos don't quite capture the absolute fear or excitement that manifests as you test the limitations of the vehicles with increased ambition and discover that roads are suggestions.You can travel a road 3 times and it will be different every time as the terrain becomes a custom sculpted mash signed by you.  In these moments, you feel your heaviness visualized by the scar it leaves behind.  It's like every foot of terrain is a mini-game where finessing your steering and acceleration reward you by permitting movement under the captivity of weight.When the miracle of movement no longer graces you, the winch is the undead arm reaching out of the grave.  At times your winch makes you feel like a vehicular Bionic Commando or Spider-Man as you get pulled out of the mess you're in and you must employ strategy in selecting what to connect to lest it put you in a whole new mess.  Don't let this obvious scenario fool you, though, the winch is as versatile as it should be.Winch to a friend to have them lower you down a cliff.  Attach to the right spot on an overturned truck to right it, or secure yourself to pre-emptively avoid overturning.  Pull debris out of the way.  Cross the uncrossable river.  Maybe even tow a truck that's damaged and out of fuel.  Your very own personal tractor beam is satisfying to use every time.Each map has carefully placed vehicles, garages, fuel supplies, cloaking fields and obstacles which you must configure your trucks for and build a plan around in order to facilitate the completion of the map objective.  Positioning fuel trucks, maintenance trucks, cranes, lumber haulers, etc around the map to optimize a route proves to be satisfying.  The objective serves as a fairly standard carrot, but the real meal is the pursuit.Even though Spintires is worth it just for the authenticity in the unique experience it provides, you can't help but realize it hasn't reached its full potential yet.  It is still under active development and while it does support modding, It could benefit from more maps, multiplayer saving, different climates, real-time weather, better use of verticality, more required uses for cranes, maps with unique coop-only challenges and a larger variety in objectives.It looks good and it's better than it looks, but fully experiencing multiplayer requires patience and dedication since you can't save map progress.  As a workaround, you can decide to start with much better trucks which can reduce how long it takes to finish maps.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Spin Tires is awesome!  This game is great if you like sim games, it is not at all an arcade title.  If you are interesting in off-roading or heavy equipment I think you will enjoy this.  However, be prepared for a challenge, this game is difficult.ProsGood graphics.  Though not perfect, you will feel much immersed.Fun variety of vehicles and terrain.  Great setting (the Russian countryside?)Very challenging but fun simulation.  The challenge isn’t in how to operate your vehicles, it’s how to navigate the terrain and what tools to use.Good, premade, maps.  This is great for a couple of reasons: if you are truly stuck you can consult the internet.  It gives you an end goal, or sense of accomplishment, that is difficult to attain in procedurally generated open world games. ConsThe camera angles! The camera controls!  Yes, you will see many complaints on this.  The camera swings wildly around, constantly moving, and rarely showing you what you want to see.  I wouldn’t consider it game-breaking; you do get used to it.  However, it’s hard to imagine why the mouse control isn’t just a simple 1:1 style input you get in other sim games.  I feel the like the little Jeep Wrangler look-a-like is way underbalanced. Why isn’t there just a standard pickup? (you can add this sort of thing in through unofficial mods)

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Even though I've only played about two hours on this game so far, I find it a brilliant game. The graphics are just as they are seen in the trailer therfore amazing. The gameplay itself is also very good. There are many maps to choose from and the objectives seem to take quite a while so there is lots to do including unlocking trucks and unlocking cloaks. The trucks on the game are very customizable and depending on the truck your using can really depend on how easy or hard it is to control. I've come into various scenarios where I have had to use another truck or a tree to wrench myself out of deep dirt or rivers which is always quite good fun. I haven't completed the first map yet so it should be fun to try out the other maps. I'm also yet to try the multiplayer mode in this game which looking at a couple of gameplays look good.The only downside to the game, is that it is quite demanding (for me anyway). Basically, you'll want a dedicated graphics card to run this game on high settings. I have put most of my settings on medium or low and it works well however. I still need to purchase a graphics card at some point so I can play this as well as many other games on high graphic settings.Overall, it seems to be a fun game and the fact I got it for £11.99 (I think) was certainly worth it. Not sure I'd want to pay full price though. In my opinion, wait for it to pop up in a sale again (as I do with just about all games).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												All right. So I am an advent off-road driver. And I saw this game for $30. But I didn't feel like it was worth that much so I waited it out and bought it on sale. Needless to say, it would have been worth the full price.It is a great game, and down to the point, here is the pros and the cons.Pros:-Enviroment. Both visually attractive, yet functional. The ground reacts properly, and it is far from plain.-The Vehicles. Great array of vehicles to select from. Sure given the time period and point of game, you can't get a Jeep. But they are beautifully done, with their own perks and downsides.-Customization. You can do up your vehicles with what ever you may need to get the job done.-Physics. They're great. Muddy tires don't always get traction, and the more kit you have on your vehicle, the heavier and more likely it bogs down.-The Gameplay. Though they could have just cheaped out and made it so you just get to bog around. They added actual objectives, and side objectibes to complete. This makes the game far more interesting.Cons:-Camera Angels. Worst camera angels ever. I sent one of my fully loaded trucks down a cliff because I couldn't angel the camera to see what was directly in front of me.-Sound. Though the actual sound of what's going on in the game is awesome, it would be nice if you could set up a playlist or something.Either way, I look forwards to what more this game has to offer. I hope they will release Allied and other countries vehicles with more maps in the near future (for a reasonable price of course). So if you're like me and like to off-road, this games for you. The bonus is, it's still cheaper than doing it with your own vehicle!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												You know the mud I'm talking about. It clumps on your boots, 5 kg each, sticky and heavy and miserable to move through. In a forest fire, it produces perfectly natural clay. This mud is the kind of mud which inspires engineers to drain swamps and invent ever-larger bulldozers. Spintires is a game about this mud, about taking light trucks and progressively heavier trucks through the terrain in an attempt to outwit the mud. There is no economy in this, not when the end-of-mission screen notes you've burned 3000 liters of diesel fuel to move 8 tons of logs from one side of the map to the other. Real people would simply write off this terrain and give it up as useless, at least in its current state, and its resources unclaimable. Can you drive? Can you drive with precision, flair, style, speed? Then get out. You need none of that here. What this game wants is the person who can drive with a winch, coordinating their engine pulses with pulls, steering at one limit or the other, to escape the everpresent mud. Bring a friend. Play alone. If you think you might like churning along in first gear, fording rivers with a load of logs on a trailer behind you, this game won't judge. It's right there with you. But no matter what: you will get muddy.

												Probably one of my favorite simulators.  The realism is amazing and challenging.  I was surprised that such a well designed game was possible from a small game file compared to most games these days requiring between 10-30GB of data to download.  Many of the players have complained about the availability of vehicles/equipment, but that's because they don't understand that you have to unlock those features as part of making the game fun and challenging at the same time.  I myself fell into that trap of wondering if the game was worth buying and waited for the game to go on sale incase I didn't like it, but the game has totally become worth it after only playing for a few hours.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Even though I've only played about two hours on this game so far, I find it a brilliant game. The graphics are just as they are seen in the trailer therfore amazing. The gameplay itself is also very good. There are many maps to choose from and the objectives seem to take quite a while so there is lots to do including unlocking trucks and unlocking cloaks. The trucks on the game are very customizable and depending on the truck your using can really depend on how easy or hard it is to control. I've come into various scenarios where I have had to use another truck or a tree to wrench myself out of deep dirt or rivers which is always quite good fun. I haven't completed the first map yet so it should be fun to try out the other maps. I'm also yet to try the multiplayer mode in this game which looking at a couple of gameplays look good.The only downside to the game, is that it is quite demanding (for me anyway). Basically, you'll want a dedicated graphics card to run this game on high settings. I have put most of my settings on medium or low and it works well however. I still need to purchase a graphics card at some point so I can play this as well as many other games on high graphic settings.Overall, it seems to be a fun game and the fact I got it for £11.99 (I think) was certainly worth it. Not sure I'd want to pay full price though. In my opinion, wait for it to pop up in a sale again (as I do with just about all games).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Game is great. Between exploring everything on each map and getting all the trucks you should be in for a good deal of game time. It's really fun multiplayer and usually you will find lots of people playing it if you create a lobby. As of yet we still don't have great mod support (you can swap out trucks but originals are replaced) but I remain hopeful they'll get it in there. If you like offroading you should really enjoy your time with this game. Getting some of the larger loads of logs where they need to go can be a real challenge, as well as the river crossings. Mud deformation and attention to details in this game are top notch. It's a very focused game don't expect something epic, just some badassery with some cool trucks off road. The little orange tanker truck is my favorite.Heres some multiplayer gameplay.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												If you're interested solely in the idea of driving offroad through fairly realistic mud/water/rocks then this game does that very well.  It's not realistic to the point of being punishing but it does a good job of staying very far away from being arcade and it's satisfying to watch the simulated mud moving around as you drive through it.As for the rest of the game...it's more of a tech demo...you can load logs onto a truck from 1 or 2 log locations on the map and deliver them elsewhere to complete an achievement...you can take a trailer load of 'garage' parts to 1 or 2 spare garage locations on a map to unlock them(this is where you repair and get fuel trailers/change tires/change equipment on the trucks such as the crane attachment)....and you can offroad to "cloaking" places that obscure your map view in the beginning.  Outside of those few tasks the rest of the content has to come from you....maybe you got stuck and switch to another truck to come winch yourself out....maybe you broke a truck or need fuel so you grab yet another truck to bring repair points/fuel to yourself.....or maybe you drove through the same spot a few times and now the ruts have made you stuck.  Things can be a bit more fun if you have a friend or two(not random people) to play multiplayer with so you can convoy around together.  Over all the maps seem to be a bit small at roughly 3kmx3km(can take a while crawling in mud) and the lack of any additional missions or non-player AI means the game really does feel like a tech demo and given the terrible relations the devs have with the community I bet it'll stay like a tech demo.........BUT that doesn't stop me from recommending it to anybody that wants to do some offroading from the comfort of their home.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
 General Spin Tires is a log trucking game where you will have to overcome obstacles and rivers to get to your destination.  The game is mainly single player, although does have a multiplayer function. Personally multiplayer with friends is a much better mode as it can be a little bit boring completing scenarios on your own. Multiplayer is a great feature as you winch each other out of ruts and rivers and can be very challenging in an enjoyable way. If you lose internet connection you are kicked back to the main menu and all progress that you have completed is lost, it would be nice to save multiplayer progress. The camera views to see where you going and what you’re doing can be a little frustrating, this can be resolved by switching from 3rd person to 1st person views. The game is highly moddable which is great to play new maps and new vehicles, these mods can also be played online as long as all parties have the same mods applied. It is a shame that there are not many official game maps and it can be difficult to find high quality mod maps. One feature that I do like is a day/night cycle although I would like to see weather involved too. The game works with game controllers or steering wheels but when using manual gears is a little strange and sometimes stalls the truck. UI The main menu is simple and can select where you want to go fairly easily. In-game menus can be a little confusing when trying to apply changes to your truck or trailer. It would be nice to see a slightly clearer design when changing modifications on the vehicles. Graphics The graphics & physics are amazing even using medium graphical settings. The tire tracks leave groves in the terrain and can affect the physics on the truck including previous tire tracks. The suspension on the trucks moves extremely well, looking very realistic and sound effects also sounds great and changes on different surfaces. I would recommend this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I've been playing this game on and off ever since the tech demo first came out (the 8x8 train car on wheels mod* was amazing fun) and after having spent some time in the full game, this is here to stay.The objective is fairly simple, namely pick up logs at location A and transport them to location B, but succeeding in that is anything but simple. Essentially any time you try to take a "shortcut", the result is drowned trucks, lost loads, stuck in quicksand, the list goes on. And given that there is no time limit, there really is no excuse not to take the long and safer route around. But it does make for discovering all that the maps have to offer, which is a lot.There's a nice variety of trucks and trailers in the game, although they're all Russian. I think that's a plus, since there's not a lot of games that feature those. Great details on them too.Final note: the ambient sounds (birds, crickets, owls, etc) are downright amazing. I sometimes just turn off the lights and the engine and leave the game running for the ambient sounds.* At the time of writing, it looks like mods will, in some form or another, make it into the game eventually.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												It’s not survival horror with trucks. It’s survival horror for trucks. You as a driver, as a person, as a foot on a gas pedal and a pair of hands, don’t exist. Whether it’s because Oovee didn’t want to fuss with character models or because it’s an intentional effort to focus on the element of machines vs nature without mere humanity in the middle to muck it all up, the world of Spintires is like Maximum Overdrive, that dopey horror movie where trucks come alive and drive themselves around. Not for the cheese factor, of course.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I've clocked over 300 hours on Spintires and I'm not planning on slowing down anytime soon. I can either go for a leisurely drive in the woods or do some heavy lumber deliveries or hardcore trail runs, which ever I decide when I load Spintires I'm guaranteed to enjoy myself. The frustration of rolling the truck and losing the load really keeps you on your toes!The very best off-road game that exists at this moment in time, and I've done my searching.Here are a few reasons as to why I think this game is awesome:- Fully customisable trucks (via XML)- Challenging- Fun- involves a lot of problem solving- big tucks - fantastic modding community with hundreds of custom trucks and maps- beautiful scenery- I don't do multiplayer in games at all as most of the time its toxic and full of a holes, however Spintires is the only one I will play MP due to it being a good laugh and lots of funThere are some minor issues with the slow speed of updates, but in reality there is nothing like this game anywhere else so I take the rough with the smooth. The workshop does have some joke trucks and stuff for a bit of a laugh and there are quite a few US style 4x4's that do take the game away from what it was originally supposed to be, which is great because custom gaming is the way forward. I however love the original premise of the the old style trucks. Here are some of my fav's from the workshop:


C-6522 SGS 
A Workshop Item for Spintires
By: $GREGOR 24 RUS$

			The standard model.Addons taken from the Internet.Has its + default Addons		





Type C-4310 
A Workshop Item for Spintires
By: Shadow Lord Of Darkness Undead

			Type C-4310 truck, with two color variations. Same achievements can be earned as any Type-C truck. Unique sounds and a unique spare wheel addon.		





KrAZ-6316 
A Workshop Item for Spintires
By: msergt

			Одна из последних машин семейства «Открытие» – КрАЗ-7Э6316 с надписью «Сибирь».Автомобиль был разработан в 1988 году и на следующий год построен.Работы над этим четырехосным полноприводником были прекращены в 1991 году...		


MAN TGS 41.480 (there is a better version of this on a third party website)http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=689907356MAN TGS-26.480http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=626389035Landrover Series 1http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=670579859Landrover Series 3 110http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=690912225Landrover Discovery 1998http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=659762891TATRA 813 KOLOS by zidon (I changed the sounds because the standard is intense AF)http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=560340719TL;DR 10/10 would recommend to everyone who wants to go off-roading.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Spintires is a game about picking up logs, put them on your tractor trailer and then haul them to a drop off a kilometer or two away. The only problem is that it's  in the middle of the vast russian forests where roads are mearly suggested stretches of mud. What should be a small pick up and drop off is now a fight against ruthless terrain and fuel consumption counted in litres per minute. Rarely has going so slow been so intense.It's all thanks to the great simulation of the 4x4 and even 8x8, differential and deforming terrain. This game is fun to play alone but is on a whole other level in multiplayer with a friend. Getting stuck in mud have never been more fun.

Some things to improv on is the fact that when you download a mod for the game it automatically stops you from playing with friends. if you could make it so that the mods you install are for offline mod (single player) and then when you want to play with your friend (online) you are able to without it stopping you completly.  I therfore urge you to buy this game and play it with your hearts contentKind RegardsHEZZA_THE_GAMER

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												It's a special kind of game that see's me rage quitting then back playing again just a few minutes later. I can't stay mad at this game because for all it's harshness, I appreciate it's difficultly. The environmets are beautifully rendered, and the vehicles are unlike any other driving games I've ever owned.The level I justed played saw me at one point with three out of four vehicles immobilsed; one underwater in a river, one on its roof after a winching mishap, and one up to it's windows in mud with a load of logs on. I had one old pickup truck left with nothing but some chains on it's back wheelsand a winch  to help it through this mud. It took me an hour but I got all those vehicles rescued, back on their wheels and repaired. One of the most satisfying hours of gaming I've experienced in a long time.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												This game is seriously amazing, OK so I don’t like the cloakin’ thing or the camera angles and there is really no tuition. However after a few hours of play it becomes clear what you need to do and boy, is it fun! Slugging through the Russian forests in big Russian trucks gives you a simulation feel to how one would go about green roadin’, after you have passed every map on standard the advanced mode makes you think about ways to overcome the obstacles and deliver your cargo. Yes sometimes the graphics lag and yes the camera isn’t perfect and yes you can’t map controls to a steering wheel and feel like you are really driving a big truck, yes the funny Russian translations say “water damages truck” rather than get out of that pond idiot BUT... X360 controller a bit a practice and this game is well worth many hours you would spend doing nothing... OH and it runs perfectly on Surface PRO-1!Thank you small little company (your own words) for creating this, this game rocks!!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Update: May 2015Still waiting on mod support, new maps..., something, anything.Update: Feb 2015The recent update is a major improvement from the backslide of negative tweaks. The maps have overhauled and there's been a lot of little tweaks here and there. The new controller layout is far more complete and I rarely have to switch between it and mouse/keyboard like I used to. I still think the camera needs some work.All it needs now is the long promised mod support and I'll be happy with it. Thankfully, that project is the first priority by the developer now.Original: Oct 2014The biggest obstacle by far is the camera. I want to love this, it's been hard to put down so far, but the camera is the most bass ackwards I've ever seen.It's like some demented party game where you've got a partner whose sole purpose is making things sure you can't see what you're doing. Imagine trying to drive while someone holds your head in their hands, points it any direction except forward and covers one eye and half the other once in a while for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.There's so much potential, in a sense, it's almost like a puzzle game in that you have you contantly have to reassess your choice in path and angles. The physics and attention to detail are impressive, but whoever's in charge of programming that camera needs to be taken out back and beaten with bats. Might make for a good customer appreciation party.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I'll try and keep it short and simple.Single player: The game has a more than usual initial learning curve and at first you'll hate it but once you get use to everything it's quite easy. It would be easy to just give up with it but I recommend you at least give a day or two to get familiar with how the truck mechanics work. The game is very slow paced and you'll be getting stuck in the mud a lot. Only the two 8 wheeled vehicles are any good at carrying medium to heavy loads on muddy terrain.Game objectives are to bring lumber to saw houses. A map can have 1 or more. Optional tasks are unlocking extra vehicles, opening garages and doing fuel runs.Multi-player: I recommend you play SP first before attempting MP for a better experience. At first I wasn't interested in trying it but it turned out to be much more fun than playing SP. The game plays the same as SP only you now have up to 3 players to help  you complete the objectives. Someone can open the garages, someone can do fuel and everyone else do lumber.At the time of writing the game has taken a turn for the worst with a recent update. MP was very much stable before but now has a whole host of issues from truck collision problems to game crashes. Right now it's practically unplayable. This may obviously be fixed but that's yet to be known.The lobby system is quite poor. You'll spend 15 minutes trying to find a decent game unless you already have others to play with. Connection problems are rife with games being hosted from home connections rather than dedicated servers. Lots of connection time outs and players generally being incompetent at hosting games. However, if you're lucky to enough to get a good game with good players then it's a fun experience.I'll feel bad giving it a bad review just for the poor MP as SP alone makes it worth it.

Also in the multiplayers mode there is no VoIP to communicate, so you'll always have to stop in the mud and maybe get stuck in order chat with other players.Should not cost more than £10, unless more game content is added.

												The best offroading game on the market, no questions asked. Just ignore all the other people who say; "Not worth $30.00, too little content". What they are forgetting is that this game was made by 3 PEOPLE. An artist, a programmer, and a producer, that's it. They're going to update the game to add more content, in fact, there was a HUGE update just recently which improved every single game map and added completely new features. I knew from the moment the Kickstarter was funded that this game was gonna go places. And now that it's on steam, it's like a dream come true. Driving an 8-wheel drive truck across the muddy, boggy Russian taiga is one of the most envigorating experiences I've had in my gaming life.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I believe that one quote from the map in Comapny of Heroes about mud here, mud there, mud swallowed the tank, etc., applies here. I fell of a ledge in a small little jeep and half of the front sank into a mud pit and the guy inside probably suffocated and died. 5/5!On a serious note: This game is a rugged truck driving simulation, a fun one with multiplayer and a variety of maps to explore, but there really isn't much else too it. Don't buy this game if you expect a deep campagin, thrilling story, or are easily drawn into a rage when your truck's wheels end up digging themselves deeper in the mud and you get stuck. Buy this game if you want a really well made simulation game without any major bugs, a well made physics engine in respect to the mud (You can theoretically shape the terrain with your tires and mud does get stuck to your vehicle in clumps), pretty enviroment that does have day and night cycles, or just love big, rugged, tough vehicles driving through forest roads. Some are even military grade :D

Posted: October 6, 2016
												I had hopes for Spintires, but sadly it turned out to be another early access money grabbing scheme' It appears the dev's added just enough content to justify a public release, sat back and watched the money roll in, baited more people into buying by promising loads of updates that never came, then when they'd made enough money they just said see ya and ran off into the sunset with everyones money.Based on the content available i'd value the game at around £4/$6 , so the £19.99 price tag is so ludicrous that I cant help but laugh. People complain about No Man's Sky being a rip off for £40, but then they pay £20 for what is essentially a tech demo of a semi-fun logging simulator......

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												I really enjoy watching the suspension flex, and the diff lockers and all wheel drive is realistic. This game is awesome. I also love the gearbox, I do wish it was manual though, so I could switch gears. The mods by the way are SOOOO easy to get, you don't even have to use Steam Workshop, you can get them through the match. I have never had a problem with any of the Steam websites and I have no protection on my PC right now. The game in total is really fun to play, especially multiplayer. It's fun to work together, I love towing people out of the mud, or up hills. I hope this comment helped., And I will see you on the dirt track!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												It's a special kind of game that see's me rage quitting then back playing again just a few minutes later. I can't stay mad at this game because for all it's harshness, I appreciate it's difficultly. The environmets are beautifully rendered, and the vehicles are unlike any other driving games I've ever owned.The level I justed played saw me at one point with three out of four vehicles immobilsed; one underwater in a river, one on its roof after a winching mishap, and one up to it's windows in mud with a load of logs on. I had one old pickup truck left with nothing but some chains on it's back wheelsand a winch  to help it through this mud. It took me an hour but I got all those vehicles rescued, back on their wheels and repaired. One of the most satisfying hours of gaming I've experienced in a long time.
