												Best driving simulator I've played.What this game does well is be realistic. The mud looks and acts perfectly. The game is challenging, and sometimes frustrating, but that is what makes it good because you have to actually think instead of just mindlessly driving around.My only complaint would be the camera angles can be a little annoying, but it's not a game breaker.Highly Recomment this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												This game is seriously amazing, OK so I don’t like the cloakin’ thing or the camera angles and there is really no tuition. However after a few hours of play it becomes clear what you need to do and boy, is it fun! Slugging through the Russian forests in big Russian trucks gives you a simulation feel to how one would go about green roadin’, after you have passed every map on standard the advanced mode makes you think about ways to overcome the obstacles and deliver your cargo. Yes sometimes the graphics lag and yes the camera isn’t perfect and yes you can’t map controls to a steering wheel and feel like you are really driving a big truck, yes the funny Russian translations say “water damages truck” rather than get out of that pond idiot BUT... X360 controller a bit a practice and this game is well worth many hours you would spend doing nothing... OH and it runs perfectly on Surface PRO-1!Thank you small little company (your own words) for creating this, this game rocks!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												I can honestly say that I was positively surprised by this game. My expectancy was that it would be boring, but im all for trying new games when I get bored of my old ones, so bought it anyways.IT IS AWESOME.There might be some issues sometimes, like no Inside camera, or kind of suckish physics at times. (Trucks and trailers bending in the craziest ways) but it is still an amazing game that will keep you entertained for hours upon hours.Superb game. Looking forward to mod support & better achievements.Edit 27-03-2015:I unfortunately have to re adjust my previous review, since the recent updates the game has absolutely not improved, the updates have ruined the game in such a way that it is no longer as entertaining to play as it was before. Sure, graphics are better, and trucks are more accurately modelled, but the GUI is terrible, the promises that are made are not met, and the updates are not properly "beta" tested before going live. Resulting in an upset community, and endless loop of updates that actually dont really add anything.Would I recommend the game now? No, not worth the full price. Get it with a 80% discount or something.Wait for a year longer, and lets see how it is then. Game can still be entertaining, but its full potential is absolutely not met.Ezu out~

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Update: May 2015Still waiting on mod support, new maps..., something, anything.Update: Feb 2015The recent update is a major improvement from the backslide of negative tweaks. The maps have overhauled and there's been a lot of little tweaks here and there. The new controller layout is far more complete and I rarely have to switch between it and mouse/keyboard like I used to. I still think the camera needs some work.All it needs now is the long promised mod support and I'll be happy with it. Thankfully, that project is the first priority by the developer now.Original: Oct 2014The biggest obstacle by far is the camera. I want to love this, it's been hard to put down so far, but the camera is the most bass ackwards I've ever seen.It's like some demented party game where you've got a partner whose sole purpose is making things sure you can't see what you're doing. Imagine trying to drive while someone holds your head in their hands, points it any direction except forward and covers one eye and half the other once in a while for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.There's so much potential, in a sense, it's almost like a puzzle game in that you have you contantly have to reassess your choice in path and angles. The physics and attention to detail are impressive, but whoever's in charge of programming that camera needs to be taken out back and beaten with bats. Might make for a good customer appreciation party.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Asking $30 for this game is ridiculous.  Is it a good game?  Sure, as long as you like the incredibly limited content they provide you, and you don't want to EVER see updates.  The devs will tell you, "a major update should be out within the next month," and then nothing will happen for 6-8 months.  When it finally releases (if it ever does), you'll find out that they changed the mud from light brown to tan.  Oh, and they took a feature that they fixed in the last update and revert it because that's what the lead programmer prefers, and what the community wants doesn't matter.  I've met rocks that are better at communicating and meeting deadlines.  The ONLY thing redeeming this game is that they finally allowed modders to make trucks and maps.  Of course, the maps aren't *officially* supported yet, but that's ...coming soon... (read 2018), so you have to install them manually, and if you install more than a dozen or so, you can't scroll through them in map selection, so you can't play them all.  You have to go back in and take maps out or edit file names so they don't show.  And a lot of the trucks are overpowered rigs that couldn't get stuck in a 50 foot deep tar pit.  Don't get me wrong, there are some phenomenal modders out there (Bregel, I'm looking at you!) but you'll have to pick around to find them.  At least the trucks will automatically download in MP games if someone doesn't have them.  Of course, if you happen to have a custom map, and you want to play MP, you better make sure everyone else has it too, as they don't automatically cross.  TLDR:  Not bad for $12 or so, but not remotely delivering on what could be an epic game.  And you'll get bored before you'll get an update.  Just wish there were a "Meh" rating option.

Now, to get on with the whole nonsense about the Developers and Publisher. Oovee - Publisher, and Pavel - Dev, have had problems agreeing on things. Some Rumors were that Pavel abandoned, or Oovee stopped Pavel from updating it. Other sites where Pavel is known have seen him post about this matter, and hes still updating it, and posting copies on sites. So personally, I just think Oovee wont let Pavel make his game how he wants.No hard feelings to either of them, I just want to see this game revived, and continue to be updated.This is an Amazing game, and i think most people here can agree, We all want this game to live on.

												I completely recommend this game who likes to play trucking, offroading, and just fun games. Ive always wanted a game like this and finnally one came out and im more than pleased. Anyway, If i could ask for 4 things in a future update, I would ask for, a Map Editor, a T-54 Soviet Tank, a way to save more than one game, and Workshop support. Other than that, this game is well worth the $30.00.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												The physics are astonishing. I've never seen such believable modelling of tyres and mud. The trucks all behave like they weigh something (a concept overlooked in some games). Genuinely for the first 30 mins I was just gawking at how good the world and models are.Driving options seem realistic enough. By default the steering doesn't auto-centre, which I quite like. There's also options for turning diff-lock and all-wheel-drive on/off, though the terrain is so bad that I found I had to have both on at all times.Last point is that it takes some patience. It takes forever to get anywhere and it seems that to complete 8 deliveries of lumber would take an insane amount of time.If you like driving games and have an attention span of more than a few minutes you'll enjoy this

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												This is my first review ever on a game, but here it goes. I'm going to start off with a list of the upsides of the game followed by the things that really bothered me about it.Upsides- Beautiful graphics- The missions are very simple which isn't much of an upside, as they are the same on every map. But once you get into the map and uncover the cloaking points, it makes it very hard to walk away. - Very realistic mud physics, haven't seen any other game come close.- Provides multiplayer support.Now for the downsides-Camera view could have been done waaay better, it is a serious pain.-The multiplayer support could've been done better also. The lobby starter/owner basically serves as the server host, meaning everyone's ping is sh!t. I literally had a friend playing on my lobby using my internet (fiber optic, mind you) and his ping was still over 100. -The devs have seriously dropped the ball on what could be a seriously amazing game if they would put forth the effort and make more content for the paying customers.- I believe it comes in overpriced at $30.00, for the fact that you only recieve 5 maps and 7 trucks. In my personal opinion, I love this game. It has a lot of downsides, but if you're an offroad enthusiast like myself then I think you will enjoy it as well. I would wait until you find it on sale though as I do not agree with it being $30, unless the devs get off their butts and make a dlc pack of some sort.

content:
Posted: January 27
												The game (simulator) has really good graphics and good mud physics. The most realistic I've ever seen in a driving game. Its a very casual game to just chill with friends working across the map or by yourself. The only downside is the length of time it takes to discover the whole map and complete the objectives (on MP as you can save progress on SP). The map while driving can often seem repetetive but there are many scenic spots, and some unique gems along the way. There is no better truck/mudding simulator and if you're into modding there are plenty of vehicles to play around with on the workshop.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												In this game you play as Sergei Porosov, a Russian truck driver. You follow his life in what feels like a fairly linear single player campaign, spanning almost the entire 20th century. You start as a teenager during the end of the first world war, hauling timber on your horse cart. The fact that you can style your horse cart with SPINTIRES™-, game company logo or silly memes ruins my immersion quite a bit, but you can simply refrain from putting bling on your cart, or any of the other trucks that you drive further on in the game. The game continues into the second world war where you haul mystery cargo in a large trucks to camps. This is where im going into SPOILERS. The mystery cargo turns out to be jews, leftist sympathisers, gays and other "unwanted" folk to concentration camps, since your home is now part of Great Germany. This is where the linearity of the campaign breaks down into two roads that I'm still pretty indecisive on. You can from here on decide to continue work for the Germans by hauling jews to camps (it pays A LOT more than the other option, letting you upgrade your truck with things such as a radio, a Hitler bobble head for the dashboard and even pay for access to the much smoother Autobahn roads).The other option is to refuse helping the third reich and instead join the Russian resistance fighters. This is where the game shifts to an over-the-shoulder shooter, and to me it doesn't make any sense whatsoever. The environments work alright for a shooter, but there aren't many guns and it's infantry only. I was hoping to destroy some German tanks, or even better, commanding one all the way to Berlin. Big fan of the T-34s.Depending on the choice you make during WW2 you end up with either an intense truck racing sim (with the Autobahn upgrades you go basically 200km/h all the time and it's pretty intense) or an OK shooter. Helping the nazis is much more fun.Anyway the game touches the whole concentration camps theme with sensitivity so the devs are pretty mature with the theme. All in all a pretty eye opening experence.Great game. Get it on a sale.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Me and my friend were saving up for gta 5 when they postponed it. Very dissappointed, we wanted something else to play since we had the money saved up. We enjoy trucks and vehivles in general. He mentioned this game, so we bought it. Not really knowing what to think of it, we hopped right in. This game is different than most games i've played, it's a nice break from the fast paced shooters and racers that are out there. It makes you think about what you need to haul, and how to do it. Do i take a uaz to scout out the cloaked areas? Or do I just find my way with the big truck? It's really innovative, and fun. I do hope to see a lot of improvements though, such as, Mod supported multiplayer, first person view, a wider range of vehicles, and a couple of more maps. I have not found many bugs or glitches in the game at all since i've played it. It's a very fun game with hours of hauling and exploration, if you're looking for break in most games playstyle and mechanics i'd reccomend this to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Very fun game, amazing graphics and physics.  The name says it all, driving huge soviet military vehicles through harsh deep muddy terrain.  The game is lacking a bit in content at the moment, but the recent news changes the outlook for Spintires.  Now that they are developing for Spintires again I would recommend watching it, if you really want to take the plunge and get muddy I would recommend buying on a sale. The multiplayer was fun, there just needs to be more objectives, or gametypes.  It's lacking a bit in the "to do" department,  since basically it consists of exploring the map, and getting to the objectives without crashing or getting stuck.  Very challenging and frustrating at times, the winch is the holy grail of survival once you hit the deep nasty..better hope there is something to winch off to nearby.  Very casual, a bit of strategy and loads of fun and eye candy.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Really enjoying my time with SPINTIRES. I think it grabs me in a way that takes me back to being a kid in rural america when I would be outside in the dirt and mud playing with my Tonka trucks and Hotwheels cars. Pretending I was hauling stuff like grown-ups did, with their powerful and larger than life vehicles. Now I can do that without getting all covered in mud! :D SPINTIRES is a fun/relaxing game. There are objectives, but you can take them at your pace. Explore the maps. Enjoy the challange of a particular hill, or river. I wish I was better with words, but I am not. So I'll just say, I really recommend this game if you like simulators, offroading, old russian trucks, and the freedom to do as you please in games. 8 out of 10! Always room for improvements though. (More maps and vehicles. Steam mod support and so on)

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Coincidentally or not, Spintires was very recently struck by a rash of seemingly out-of-nowhere bugs that have caused it to crash or malfunction in various ways. And according to this post on Reddit, it's actually Zagrebelnyj's doing: It alleges that he's inserted “time bombs” into the game code that are responsible for the troubles. There have been four of them so far, each eventually fixed—unofficially—by a user.Oovees, however, denied what it called “press speculation” about the game being intentionally sabotaged. “The situation on the bug is that we became aware of a major bug last week that caused the game to stop for some users. We have been working on this with Pavel since it came up. Progress on the next planned update has been suspended while we sort the bug issue,” it wrote on its forums. “We believe we have now identified the problem and are now testing at this very moment a hot fix provided by Pavel, who is also ready to help further if needed. We're fully focused now on making the game work properly again, so please allow us to get this sorted first and we'll then be able to explain what has caused this and then carry on with future updates we have planned.”Despite the apparent imminence of a fix, however, Oovee has suspended sales of Spintires on Steam. It's still listed, but there's currently no option to purchase it, or even follow or add it to a wishlist. I'm not a coder, but that seems like a rather extreme step to take in the process of fixing a conventional bug—and I'm not a conspiracy theorist, but the sudden appearance of crippling bugs nearly two years after a game's release seems a little hinky, too.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Alright, writing an new review to this game due to all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ raging over everything that's "wrong" with this game. First off, this game IS NOT a "cash grab", as I've heard it called, you're completly ignorant to call a game with this quality a "cash grab" game, or a game made quickly for cash, and not player enjoyment. This game is VERY good, when you look at the small indie game studio who created it, you can't complain about some issues here and there. For everyone who is complaining about changes to the BETA branch of the game, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥people, it's the BETA section for a reason, it's for them to test new systems and get feedback. This is not an unfinished game, as far as I'm concerned I've been given exactly what was shown to me, this is not an early access game, this wasn't meant to cater to your every need. Stop begging for features that YOU want and then call it "unfinished" when they are delivered to you that week. If you haven't been in a game development position, don't speak. It's not easy dealing with idiots crying about features they want in the game, and still trying to deliver a solid product. Are there any major bugs in Spintires? No. There isn't, not that I've seen, just some gameplay adjustments as a test. You got your individual map saves. You got your steering wheel support. Now move on, stop flaming the game, and play it. Oh, your friend can't connect to the server, but you can? Sounds like your friend has an issue, not Spintires.-----Since I went off on that rant, let me tell you about Spintires. Spintires is an offroad simulator based in Russia, with Russian military vehicles. I myself love games like Rigs of Rods (Soft body physics driving simulator, with mud and all that fun stuff), Beam.NG (soft body car physics sandbox), and other games like it. If you've played these games, or they sound fun, Spintires is your game. There's no softbody physics (thank God), but there's one hell of a mud setup in it. If you're not one of these twitchy kids who keep raging because this struggling little indie studio doesn't do exactly what they want, and are a serious offroader in real life, or like physics/driving games, you'll love Spintires. Get this game, don't listen to the hype, you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												SPINTIRES is a great offroad simulation, a genre I really like, and I'd like to see more games like this. However, there are some issues that will hopefully be fixed with future updates. My review refers to the single player mode only, as I haven't tested the multiplayer mode yet. In single player mode, I compleated each map. Here are some of the issues i'd like to see fixed in the future:- The camera control is not intuitive, it's really hard to get the camera into the position you want. I'd also like to see more camera positions to choose from.- The maps are looking really similar, it would be great to have some more diversified maps, with snow, ice, sand or some rock climbing, not only mud.- It would be great to have different missions, not only transporting logs, but also rocks or other types of load.- I really like the places where you have to pick up the logs yourself with a crane, unfortunately those places don't exist on many maps.- It is weird, that you only have to load 3 to 6 logs to fully load your truck, i'd really prefer loading it up with the real amount of logs I'm carrying, why not counting the logs? The objective could say there are 20 logs required, and you can load up as much logs as you like until your trailer is full, and you deliver as much points as logs are loaded on your truck?- It would be great if I could control the crane more precisely, especially when rotating the Grabber.- I don't like the way the maps are masked. It's really strange to drive to a certain point to reveal a circular area of the map. I'd understand it if those points would be lookout points where you could really see lots of the map. But I'd prefer a masking that would always reveal a small area around my truck while driving, just like the fog of war in strategy games. That would be like drawing a map while driving, and I think it would be more realistic and more interesting to really try each road and figure out where it ends.I can't wait to see more of this game, and hopefully some of these points will get fixed with future updates!

												In principle I love this game but it is plagued by some very gamebreaking bugs and problems. Every game session starts with the trucks clipping into eachother and exploding spectacularly. Every game session ends early with a "Oops Spintires Has Stopped Working" error. I am so disappointed that Oovee even allows such broken releases. As of now the game is nice and pretty but utterly unplayable. Do not buy this game now. Check back on this game in a year or two.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												A strangely relaxing game. If you'd asked me if I'd like to chill out by driving Russian trucks through waist-deep mud, I probably would've looked at you funny, but there we are. In that sense I find it more similar to a game like Take On Mars than to another truck-themed game like Euro Truck Simulator. It also doesn't hurt if you think Russian military trucks are nifty.But this game does not appear to be for everyone. If you are considering buying it, I'd advise waiting for a sale to bring it down to, say, the $15 range, and keep your finger on that refund button. It's also very interesting from a technical point of view, since, as far as I'm aware, there isn't another driving game that models offroad driving and terrain deformation in quite so much detail. As I've suggested earlier in the review, it's oddly relaxing watching your truck try to wade through fully deformable mud and water, and a small thrill when it manages to finally climb out the other side. Though, on the other hand, it's at first mildly frustrating getting bogged down in that same situation. I say at first because, like Kerbal Space Program, a short-term failure is merely an invitation to mount an elaborate rescue mission, and the scope of these rescue missions broadens when you introduce other players in co-op.The developer and publisher have some issues with communication, and have suffered storms of drama in their relationship in the past, so the future of the game's development is far from bright. However, even with that, I think what's here (and what will be added in the upcoming, nearly-finished, update) is well worth the asking price when the game is discounted down to what I suggested.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												I bought Spintires when it was first offered on Steam in late 2013 or early 2014 (I forget exactly when it was first offered). Back then it showed a lot of promise and even though it was still being developed, I could see it was going to be a great off-road game. This year however the game has gotten worse. What use to be somewhat challenging has become too easy. Even in “Hardcore” mode you can almost go through any of the provided maps leaving the shifter in auto and not using AWD (All Wheel Drive) or the Differential lock. They even modified some of the more challenging areas in a few of the maps such as the angles of a few hills, tree placement (most notably near one of the unlockable garages on the Coast map).The saving graces of the game are the visual aesthetics and the number and quality of third party mods. So, if you’re looking for an off-roading log transporting game that isn’t too difficult to master, you’ll be very happy with this game. The ability to play multiplayer co-op with up to 3 others from literally all over the world is also enjoyable and makes the world feel just slightly smaller. If you’re looking for a challenge that requires some knowledge with shifting and when to use AWD/Differential lock you will find this game soaring lacking…

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												When I feel tense or down, there's nothing quite as soothing as taking on Siberian taigas for hours. This game is staunchly monotonous, don't be fooled, but it's a good kind of gripping simplicity. It's just dirt. How do you get enough grip to take all your fuel or logs up that hill? This game can actually teach you a lot about real-life driving in challenging earth. One important note: Do not even think about playing this without a controller. You need variable input for the accelerator, so that you can be gentle. That is the key to conquering dirt!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												First off I would like to congratulate the guys at Oovee for a great launch.  Unlike some big name developers both the single player and multiplayer worked nearly flawlessly at launch.  While Spintires is not perfect it is nonetheless an awesome and very enjoyable game.  I say game because the game mechanics turn this into more of a puzzle game with truck and mud skins than a simulator.  More on that in a sec.This is truly a sandbox (mud pit) environment.  You are presented with a few vague goals to deliver logs to one or more objectives.  While this is the obvious objective the game often creates more objectives of its own.  You can choose to just deliver the logs (no easy task I might add) or make up your own objectives. Those that complain that there is not enough variety are playing the game wrong.  If you keep rescuing your vehicle to the garage you miss some of the most enjoyable missions / puzzles the game has to offer.The graphics, environment, deformable terrain are fantastic.  Pavel has done an amazing job creating a fantastic environment in which to experiment.  Mission types.Exploration. Can be varied by forcing yourself to use a particular vehicle.Expansion.  Activating new garages. Rescue. Seems I have spent nearly half the game rescuing an overturned or swamped vehicle.Repair and Refuel.Race. Against other players or against the clock.The game can be frustrating in many ways.  It took me a day or so to figure out how to activate other garages.  It took even longer to figure out the crane controls.  These are not very well documented in the manual.  Of course this is made even more infuriating in that key customization / mapping is very poor.  The crane controls should not share keys with the vehicle control keys.Here are some issues that added to the entertainment (frustration).  The winch is unrealistically powerful.  There is no way a simple winch is going to pull a fully loaded logging truck up a steep incline through the mud.  It is also impossible for a winch to right a fully loaded tractor trailer laying on its side down a 45 degree slope.  Tone down the winch.  Unless the pulling vehicle is fitted with spade anchors a lighter vehicle will not be able to pull a heaver vehicle.  The lighter vehicle will pull itself to the load.  That does happen in game but the pull strength is still too much.  I would suggest the addition of a wrecker module that can be mounted on the truck chassis; a module that includes spade anchors, an adjustable boom and a high pull strength winch.Winch points.The winch points in game are not always realistic. Can’t winch to stumps but can winch to fallen trees, sometimes saplings.  Kind of funny to pull a huge mastodon loaded with logs by winching to a small fallen tree.  Winch points should be on stumps and the fallen trees should be movable.  Been a few times I’ve gotten the trailer trapped on one of these fallen sapling and had to dump load  and lift the trailer over the sapling with the crane.  I don’t know if the engine can support it but it would be nice if trees had a load limit at which point the tree would snap.  Logs can’t be winched.Seems obvious.  Having worked around the logging industry this is a common practice.  Smaller vehicles can winch logs through dense areas to clearing for loading on larger trucks.  Also logs are often winched up from inaccessible areas to a loading position.  This also adds additional mission types where logs have to be pulled to a collection area.  Also the logs can be used to form obstacles that need to be cleared.  Enough with the mud.  Yes the mud provides a formidable obstacle but I feel it is overused.  Steep inclines, sand, rocks, logs, ditches, and abandoned vehicles are also suitable obstacles that are under utilised or not present at all.Damage model is off.I can double roll my vehicle down a steep rocky incline and receive less than 100 points of damage.  Yet if I put any speed down a dirt track I can accumulate 300+ points from just a few bumps in the road.  Come on these are off road trucks.  I can see receiving damage from large bumps and hitting rocks at high speed.  Surly rolling a vehicle more than 360 degrees should do more damage than a few dirt bumps.  Logs have no collision modeling.When loading the logs in a wooded area I discovered that I could swing the logs through the trees like they were not there.  This made loading easier but not very effective as a simulation. Fuel is a bit contrived.I get that the fuel adds an additional mechanic to the game but since the maps are so small at 1km/1km I find it impossible to believe any of the vehicles can’t get across the map without needing fuelling.  This is another example of the puzzle mechanic at play.Map is too small.I can not understand why the game is limited to one square kilometre.  I like the map exploration portion of the game.  Unfortunately the area is so small and the cloaking points so few exploration is a short objective.  I would like to see 10km / 10km maps!  Also make the cloaking points smaller and drop the black tornado looking thing.  If the map were bigger the fuel issue above would not be as obvious.  The Camera.By far my biggest frustration.  While I’ve become comfortable with the camera setup for driving in most cases, for loading logs manually the camera is impossible.  Enough has been already said of the camera by other.  I will wait and see what the next patch brings.  Key mapping.I have a whole keyboard.  Every function should be assignable to a key. Start engine, and crane controls should have their own completely mapable controls.     Additional feature I would like to see.Larger maps 10km / 10km.Key mapping for all controls.   The aforementioned wrecker attachment. Road repair and bridge building.  I would like to see the addition of concrete and steal culverts / pipes and gravel building material.  Dump truck, dozer and loader.  Maybe a flatbed trailer to carry the dozer.  I can see a goal where before the logs can reach the objective a road has to be repaired, a bridge constructed and perhaps a fresh cut made in a hillside to cerate a safe path for the logging trucks. I don’t want to see a full up road building sim.  Just enough to simulate the effort sometimes required to get the logs and then get them to the objective.  This engine is suppos to support deformable terrain so why not add the additional deformation objectives.  I`m sure Pavel can great an amazing mechanic to simulate the effect of rocks and gravel dumed in flowing water.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This a fantastic game, the graphics are good, the physics are amazing, the actual gameplay is great but like many others have said on here it seems unfinished. There is just not enough content. There are only a handful of vehicles and the scenery is pretty much the same for every map. The Devs have said they are adding more content in the future, including a cockpit view, weather, and more vehicles so the game will improve. If you can get over a few minor things I would definatly buy it. It is well worth the money.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												SpinTires Is fantastic and aptly named also, in game the majority of the fuel indicator go to spinning tyres. Easy to pickup game mechanics however difficult to master. Spintires is one of those strangely addictive games, I cant quite put my finger on why this is so but it is. Now with multi player you can convoy with your friends also. This makes things easier but also adds another layer of complexity as the mud and dirt gets churned up by them however getting bogged it it up to them to come to your aid or visa-versa. Fantastic concept, well executed. Also wondering what Updates will come later as well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I love this game. Such a mellow and methodical game to play. The physics are top notch, my jeep bounces around exactly as I would expect on that terrain. The graphics are great looking (and it's only a 600mb DL).(Read the store page for a game description, not gonna drag it out) Not much to do except deliver logs and equiptment to log factory/base, would be good if they added steam workshop to this so these guys can work their magic. Has multiplayer so you can do stuff together, but you cant save it. I'd kill (literally) to see some mud pluggin' 1000hp hill climbers to rip around in, or  monster trucks and a monster truck arena ,this game has exactly what it needs to make a great monster truck game, physics wise(I know its not the the style of the game, but sometimes you just wanna tame a beast). It would also be great if there were other missions...........log truck rescue/urgent supply deliveries.............uh, I don't know, I'm just throwing ideas, but I'm just saying, for the price you're asking, you need more playability.The main draw back is the view! Dat damn view! I'd love a 1st person, but FFS, pleeeeaaaaasssseeee, for the of god, make the view like a GTA style view, so the pan around is smooth, I got stuck on my side today and the view would not let me see a tree and my winch point in the same shot, I had to drive another truck 10 minutes from base to rescue a truck 5 metres from a dozen trees. Please use the beta n beat the crap out of it, and get us a good view.Overall, great game, mellow methodical beautiful, needs more content, dat view!!!,  needs to be on steam workshop, things will happen then

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I saw this game when it first came out.. I showed it to my buddy and we both agreed it was something to keep an eye on..1 year later, I had forgotten all about it, I get a gift copy from my buddy..Lets go he says..All right I say..1 hour in, I hated it.. I mean I freakin' hated it.. Stinkin camera, piece of crap.. No hot key for the winch disconnect.. I couldn't even make the right mouse button my gas.. I freakin hate that..The funny thing was, as much as I hated it, as much as I grumbled and growled about the things I couldn't do, I kept on playing it.. Found myself thinking about it while I wasn't playing it.. That stinkin' game!! Most games that irritate me, as much as this one did at the start, end up getting shelved by me..But not this one, this one had become my Moby♥♥♥♥♥♥. My White Whale.. A freakin' video game had become my white whale.. Fast forward a week, 49 hours of game time later and I can't get enough.. All the things that bugged me no longer bug me.. The camera that I said I couldn't stand, and is the No 1 gripe from most, no longer an issue.. I love how the camera works now.. Once you get the hang of it's great..It's no longer my white whale.. It's now my go to game.. Coop is a hoot, single player is just as fun..This game is a sleeper.. It will frustrate you at the start.. But the intense rush it gives, even after the tiniest success, will suck you in hard.. You will strive to get better, to do it better..5 maps in the game and a good mod com.. This games got legs..8.5/10I've uploaded several screen shots, all public.. Any shots with another vehicle trailing are all single player with second vehicle in tow..   Cheers and have fun..

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												I've had ups and downs with this game so far.  First bought it last year shortly after its release.  Its alot of fun and very addictive even more so if playing Muliplayer with friends.  It was early access and things were lookin bright for the future of SpinTires.  Then darkness.........No news No updates for nearly half a year.  Then they come back strong with news of devolopment and a "free" map that just served to slap us in the face as if they did us a huge favor.  And "communication" troubles even though I don't believe that for a second we will never know the real reason.   When playing I have this feeling its not a finished game and they are talking about DLC's.  eh well your not squeezing any money out of me cause your past track record is just silence in developing this game.  So far this logic is in line with the big name company's use DLC's to complete a game thats half finished.  Well F that.  I will give a thumbs up and recommend this game if you happen to purchase it while its on sale between $15 - $20 maybe lower.  Its not worth $30 in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												This game is a very realistic driving simulator. Drive soviet vehicles through mud, water and other terrains. Let's get to the review.Spintires is an offroad driving game where you get behind the wheel of a number of Russian vehicles and drive them through all the mud you could possibly hope for. Using only your map and compass you have to navigate the rugged terrain in order to complete objectives such as collecting and delivering lumber.+Great graphics+Quite a few different trucks, each with customisation options and they are all quite different to each other, in appearance and performance+Amazing mud physics, the deformation caused by driving through mud looks realistic and is excellent+Several maps, all of them are quite different to each other and the vehicles available vary between each one+The winch system is great and the power of it feels quite realistic+Multiplayer, particularly with friends, is a lot of fun+Driving controls are good, as are the crane controls (used for putting lumber in your trailer)+You have to discover the different parts of the map so even if you don't want to do the main objective there is a lot to do on each map+They did a very good job in making it difficult to judge water depth+/-The majority of the gameplay comes from getting yourself out of the mud, personally I think it's fun but it might put some people off-The camera controls and the camera itself are awful. The controls are very sensitive, when you zoom out it automatically zooms in making it very hard to see when using big trucks, it has a very strange centre, sometimes it pans by itself, you can only move it on the x-axis, it has awkward angles and it's difficult to get it at the angle you want-The devs still haven't added a first person camera which was promised very early on after its launch-The relationship between the dev and the community isn't great (see forums)-Infrequent updates despite being promised regular large content updatesVerdict: 8.9It's an amazingly realistic game that definetely deserves a buy, especially at the price listed.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Fantastic off-roading at your leisure.Spin Tires is not a fast paced racing game. If you want on off-road racing game, go for DiRT or Motorstorm. If you want a game where you have to carefully find your route through deep mud, trees, rocks and rivers, using everything your vehicle has to offer - including AWD, Diff Locks, Winches cranes and tow cables - then Spin Tires is the best game I know of.I recommend playing with a game pad. Personally I use a USB XBox 360 controller. The surface interraction is unlike any other game I've played, wth the mud ruts and changes in traction. I'd describe Spin Tires more as an off-road simulator than a game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												The game is great 7.5/10! Best Beginner Level: The Plains (In my opinion)Best Advanced Level: The Flood (In my opinion)This game is about you exploring areas of a unknown map to find and deliver logs to a sawmill.Sounds easy enough right? WRONG there are sketchy wooden bridges, river crossings, hardly any fuel depots, mud so deep that your truck will sink!, and having the constant reminder that your truck could become severely damaged at any givin time, Luckily you do have a winch if you get yourself in a sticky area. So the basic truck selection is alright but then again you got user made mods at the ready! some are normal some are crazy but only you can chose which one you want! There is a interior mode for the basic trucks the modded trucks have them too but they are very poor. There is only 6-7 basic levels to chose from but with the help of mods those numbers can be extended! The game has it a rough patch right now but if you go to there forum they said that the game will get better with more staff members and a new system for updates getting put into place so prepare for this game to get much better!!!Pros: Detailed Mud, Many User Made Mods!, The Dev Team is still active and working hard to bring this game to a amazing state!Cons: Cockpit Camera is poor, Automatic Gearboxs are poor (In most User Made Mods not default trucks.) Glitches sometimes take a week to a month to get fixed (That problem should go away soon!)

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												I don't know any other game where you get to agonizingly inch through a bog at a rate of about 1 km/5 hours carrying a load of lumber only overturn your truck with one bad decision, losing more than those 5 hours with no one to blame but yourself - in Hardcore mode, this truck now needs to be turned back on its wheels, it likely needs to be refueled, and it has to make its way back to the lumber - all of which may mean multiple trips with supporting vehicles. Given these stakes, the feeling of accomplishment after a success - even if it's just making it over a particularly bad hill - is equally high.Co-op is great fun too!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												You like offroading? You like Russian machinery? You like casual gaming interlaced with frustration and skill? You like mods? Then step right up and get Spintires.This game has one of the best physics out there and allows you to drive trucks around between lumber mills, logging sites, garages, and gas stations in isolated scenery where you navigate through dense forests, uneven and slippery roads, deep lakes, sticky mud, and raging rivers. Most of the vehicles are 1970s-1990s Russian vehicles, of which most are military design or often seen in popular conflicts on the news. Don't like Russian trucks, then still get this game as there is a healthy mod community that allows you to drive monster trucks, western military vehicles, cars, rally racers, tractors, modern European & Russian vehicles, etc.  It is a fun video game that can be as casual as train sim and as frustratingly tough as...whatever reality series Bear Grylls is on today.

I will give a thumbs up and recommend this game if you happen to purchase it while its on sale between $15 - $20 maybe lower.  Its not worth $30 in my opinion.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												When I feel tense or down, there's nothing quite as soothing as taking on Siberian taigas for hours. This game is staunchly monotonous, don't be fooled, but it's a good kind of gripping simplicity. It's just dirt. How do you get enough grip to take all your fuel or logs up that hill? This game can actually teach you a lot about real-life driving in challenging earth. One important note: Do not even think about playing this without a controller. You need variable input for the accelerator, so that you can be gentle. That is the key to conquering dirt!

												I love this game. Such a mellow and methodical game to play. The physics are top notch, my jeep bounces around exactly as I would expect on that terrain. The graphics are great looking (and it's only a 600mb DL).(Read the store page for a game description, not gonna drag it out) Not much to do except deliver logs and equiptment to log factory/base, would be good if they added steam workshop to this so these guys can work their magic. Has multiplayer so you can do stuff together, but you cant save it. I'd kill (literally) to see some mud pluggin' 1000hp hill climbers to rip around in, or  monster trucks and a monster truck arena ,this game has exactly what it needs to make a great monster truck game, physics wise(I know its not the the style of the game, but sometimes you just wanna tame a beast). It would also be great if there were other missions...........log truck rescue/urgent supply deliveries.............uh, I don't know, I'm just throwing ideas, but I'm just saying, for the price you're asking, you need more playability.The main draw back is the view! Dat damn view! I'd love a 1st person, but FFS, pleeeeaaaaasssseeee, for the of god, make the view like a GTA style view, so the pan around is smooth, I got stuck on my side today and the view would not let me see a tree and my winch point in the same shot, I had to drive another truck 10 minutes from base to rescue a truck 5 metres from a dozen trees. content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												The game knows exactly what it tries to deliver - offroad driving struggle in beautiful eastern european terrain. And it is successful. It is not addictive, nor is it terribly beginner friendly - but it succeeds in conjuring up a novel, enjoyable offroad gameplay experience. Game designers take heed: sometimes a sizeable chunk of immersion is all you need to captivate your audience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Bought it on sale and man, I am not disappointed. It is a surprisingly enjoyable game. I never expected a "euro-truck simulator in spacesyberia" to be so much fun, but it is. The game accurately conveys the experience of off-roading in a huge industrial cargo-hauling truck, riding across the dirt- mud- and even swamp-grounds feels very realistic as physics of said terrains' behacviour is recreated exceptionally well. Truck controls strike a good balance between a sim and arcade driving game but don't be fooled by this simplicity. Navigating a worn-down muddy green lane in a 15-ton sem-trailer is tricky and challenging. But despite being rather hard, this game can be somehow relaxing, almost a zen-like experience.The game is not without it's problems as controls can be a bit wonky at times and camera control it a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥but it seems devs are still actively working to fix the game's problems(though maybe not as fast as one would've wanted). Plus, there's an active workshop community.

												Played the Tech Demo. Loved it. Decided to buy the full game and...it seems to be More And Less fun at the same time.
